awd_titl_txt: Coordinated Cosmic-Ray Observation System Conference, July 2024 in Lincoln, Nebraska
awd_abstract_narration:
The Coordinated Cosmic-Ray Observation System Conference in Lincoln, Nebraska in July 2024 brings together experts in space weather, atmospheric science, and hydrology. The workshop explores the value of cosmic ray neutron sensors across both low and high-energy spectrums for scientific and operational goals. An outcome from the three-day conference would be a white paper on the infrastructure necessary to facilitate progress and synergies across multiple Earth and space sciences.

Measurements of high-energy neutrons on earth are vital for understanding the origin of cosmic-rays and how events from the sun impact conditions on earth. Similarly, measurements of low-energy neutrons are critical for measuring the changes of hydrogen (i.e., water) on earth and in planetary science applications (e.g., Mars rover, planned missions to the moon). However, detectors that measure each of these range of neutrons must correct for so-called contamination from variations of the other. The design of future cosmic-ray neutron detector networks must therefore consider the synergistic needs of the space weather, atmospheric science and hydrology research and operations communities. This workshop is a pioneering attempt to bring these multiple science communities together to explore the potential benefit of a coordinated neutron monitoring network across the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes and Findings

The Coordinated Cosmic-Ray Observation System Conference (October 14–16, 2024, at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln) identified seven strategic priorities to advance cosmic-ray neutron sensing (CRNS) and neutron monitor (NM) research. These outcomes address both intellectual merit—expanding scientific knowledge—and broader impacts—benefiting society through technology, education, and policy.

Intellectual Merit:

The conference fostered interdisciplinary collaboration to enhance cosmic-ray research for environmental and space weather applications. Key scientific advancements include:

  • Open Data Access: Real-time, open data sharing through FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) and TOPS (Transform to Open Science) initiatives will enhance research reproducibility and impact.
  • Improved Instrumentation: Research into alternatives to gas detectors will improve sensor efficiency and availability. Standardized testbeds will support the validation and calibration of these new designs.
  • Theoretical Developments: Higher spatial and temporal resolution neutron count analysis will refine space weather forecasting, including Forbush Decreases (FD) and Ground Level Enhancements (GLE), which impact power grids, aviation, and satellite operations.
  • Intelligent Network Design: Optimizing existing sensor networks and strategically deploying new detectors will improve data accuracy and coverage, benefiting hydrological and space weather studies.

Broader Impacts

The findings have far-reaching societal benefits, particularly in hazard mitigation, water resource management, and public engagement:

  • Environmental Monitoring: CRNS and NM data enhance drought, flood, and space weather monitoring, leading to better climate adaptation strategies, economic loss reduction, and improved early warning systems.
  • Infrastructure Protection: Improved cosmic-ray data will refine models for mitigating risks to power grids, satellites, and communication networks during solar storms.
  • Public Outreach & Education: Proposed initiatives such as grassroots webinars, new academic programs (e.g., “Astrohydrology”), and media partnerships will increase public awareness of soil moisture droughts and space weather risks.
  • Sustained Funding Strategies: To ensure long-term viability, researchers will align with government priorities, involve industry partners, and explore innovative funding approaches, emphasizing the economic and societal benefits of cosmic-ray research.

By advancing instrumentation, data sharing, and interdisciplinary applications, this initiative strengthens both fundamental research and real-world solutions, aligning with NSF’s mission to support science in service to society.
